/m/0dv3j.faq:
class="title"> Are frying, hissing or sizzling sounds considered ‘Boiling’ sounds?
class="content">

No.

class="title"> Are ‘Boiling’ sounds containing hissing sounds from gas stoves or kettles considered Present and predominant sounds? class="content">

No. When ‘Boiling’ and hissing are both salient sounds, please choose Present but not predominant.

class="title"> Are kettle whistle and pressure cooker whistle sounds considered ‘Boiling’ sounds? class="content">

No.

class="title"> Are bubbling sounds created by blowing water with the mouth or a straw considered ‘Boiling’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Boiling’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not present. To help you decide, you can check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

/m/0brhx.faq:
class="title"> Are heavily processed sounds (e.g., distorted or with audio effects) considered ‘Speech synthesizer’ sounds?
class="content">

Only consider them ‘Speech synthesizer’ if the sounds are easy to recognize.

/m/0316dw.faq:
class="title"> Are mouse clicks considered ‘Typing’ sounds?
class="content">

No, only consider them ‘Typing’ if the sound is the result of the act of writing or inputting text. If mouse clicking sounds are mixed with 'Typing' sounds, you should rate them as 'Present but not predominant'.

class="title"> Are the sounds of carriage return or bell produced by typewriters considered ‘Typing’ sounds? class="content">

Yes, as long as they are produced by a typewriter. They are considered ‘Typing’ even if the sound does not contain any writing.

class="title"> Are sounds of electronic typewriters or Perkins Brailler considered ‘Typing’ sounds? class="content">

Yes, since they are operated by inputting text by pressing keys.

class="title"> Are sounds of teletypes considered ‘Typing’ sounds? class="content">

No, since the typing is not made by a human.

/m/018vs.faq:
class="title"> Are atypical uses of the bass guitar considered ‘Bass guitar’ sounds?
class="content">

Only consider them ‘Bass guitar’ if the source is easy to recognize.

class="title"> Any bass-lines are considered ‘Bass guitar’ sounds? class="content">

Not necessarily, only consider them ‘Bass guitar’ if the sound source is an electric guitar with a long neck and 4 to 6 strings (see the Description). Remember that you can check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are (acoustic) double bass sounds considered ‘Bass guitar’ sounds? class="content">

No, since an (acoustic) double bass is not an electric guitar with a long neck and 4 to 6 strings (see the Description).

class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Bass guitar’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Bass guitar’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not present.

/m/0bm02.faq:
class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Bass drum’ sounds?
class="content">

Bad replicas or drum machines should be rated as Not present.

/m/0ngt1.faq:
class="title"> Are synthetic thunders considered ‘Thunder’ sounds?
class="content">

Only consider them ‘Thunder’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not Present.

class="title"> Are heavily processed sounds (e.g., distorted or with audio effects) considered ‘Thunder’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Thunder’ if the sounds are easy to recognize.

class="title"> Are the sounds of thunders accompanied by storm or rain considered ‘Thunder’ sounds? class="content">

If the storm or rain is also audible, Please choose Present but not predominant.

/m/0jb2l.faq:
class="title"> Are rain or wind sounds considered ‘Thunderstorm’ sounds?
class="content">

Not necessarily, only consider them ‘Thunderstorm’ if the storm has audible thunders. To help you decide, you can check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

/m/02sgy.faq:
class="title"> Are ‘Bass guitar’ sounds considered 'Electric guitar' sounds?
class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Electric guitar' sounds from ‘Bass guitar’. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Electric guitar' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples! You can also check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are sounds of electric guitars with pedals or distortion effects considered ‘Electric guitar’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Electric guitar’ if the electric guitar is easy to recognize. Typical electric guitar distortions are valid, but very weird or exaggerated distortions should be rated as Not present.

/m/07pb8fc.faq:
class="title"> Are ‘Accelerating, revving, vroom', 'Engine starting’ or shutting off sounds considered 'Idling' sounds?
class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Idling' sounds from them. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Idling' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples! If several types of engine sounds coincide, please choose Present but not predominant.

class="title"> Are idling sounds of non vehicle/automobile engines considered ‘Idling’ sounds? class="content">

Yes, see the Description.

/m/07pjwq1.faq:
class="title"> Are human imitations considered ‘Buzz’ sounds?
class="content">

Yes, as far as they phonetically imitate, resemble, or suggest the ‘Buzz’ sound (see the 'Onomatopoeia' description).

class="title"> Are any vibration sounds like 'Twang' or 'Ding' considered 'Buzz' sounds? class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Buzz' sounds from other vibration sounds like 'Twang' or 'Ding'. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Buzz' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

class="title"> Are cellphone buzz sounds considered ‘Buzz’ sounds? class="content">

No, since it exists a better category for these kind of sounds: 'Sounds of things > Alarm > Telephone > Cellphone buzz, vibrating alert '.

class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Buzz’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Buzz’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not present.

/m/0g6b5.faq:
class="title"> Are sounds of bombs or gunshots considered ‘Fireworks’ sounds?
class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Fireworks' sounds from ‘Gunshot, gunfire’ or ‘Boom’ sounds. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Fireworks' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples! Many single explosion sounds are not actually proper 'Fireworks', and also some true 'Fireworks' sounds are somewhat similar to 'Gunshot, gunfire'. The best way to be sure about this is to check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are all 'Explosion' sounds considered ‘Fireworks’ sounds? class="content">

No. Only consider them ‘Fireworks’ if they are produced by low explosive pyrotechnic devices used for aesthetic and entertainment purposes. The best way to be sure about this is to check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are heavily processed sounds (e.g., distorted or with audio effects) considered ‘Fireworks’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Fireworks’ if the sounds are easy to recognize.

class="title"> Are ‘Fireworks’ sounds containing people talking/screaming considered Present and predominant sounds? class="content">

No. When ‘Fireworks’ and people talking/screaming are both salient sources, please choose Present but not predominant.

/m/03m9d0z.faq:
class="title"> Are whoosh, swoosh and swish sounds considered 'Wind' sounds?
class="content">

Only consider them ‘Wind’ if the wind sound is natural. To help you decide, you can check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Wind’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Wind’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not present. To help you decide, you can check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are rain or thunderstorm sounds considered ‘Wind’ sounds? class="content">

No. If both wind and rain or thunderstorm are salient sounds, please choose Present but not predominant.

/m/025_jnm.faq:
class="title"> Are 'Clapping' sounds considered 'Finger snapping' sounds?
class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Clapping' sounds from ‘Finger snapping’ ones. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Finger snapping' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

class="title"> Are heavily processed sounds (e.g., distorted or with audio effects) considered ‘Finger snapping’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Finger snapping’ if the sounds are easy to recognize. If the finger snapping sound is recognizable but is accompanied by audio effects, e.g. reverb, please choose Present but not predominant.

/m/07plz5l.faq:
class="title"> Are ‘Wail, moan’, 'Yawn' or ‘Groan’ sounds considered 'Sigh' sounds?
class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Sigh' sounds from ‘Wail, moan’, 'Yawn' or ‘Groan’. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Sigh' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

class="title"> Are ‘Gasp’ sounds considered 'Sigh' sounds? class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Sigh' sounds from ‘Gasp’. The difference between gasp and sigh is that gasp is a short, sudden intake of breath while sigh is a deep and prolonged audible inspiration or respiration of air, as when fatigued, frustrated, grieved, or relieved; the act of sighing.

/m/0463cq4.faq:
class="title"> Are 'Screaming' or 'Speech' sounds considered 'Crying, sobbing'?
class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Crying, sobbing' sounds from ‘Screaming’ or 'Speech'. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Crying, sobbing' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples! If some of these similar categories are also salient in the audio sample, please choose Present but not predominant.

/m/07p6fty.faq:
class="title"> Are ‘Screaming’ sounds considered 'Shout' sounds?
class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Shout' sounds from ‘Screaming’. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Shout' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

/m/0242l.faq:
class="title"> Are the sounds of coins shaking against each other considered ‘Coin (dropping)’ sounds?
class="content">

No. The category 'Jingle, tinkle' is more appropriate for this sound.

class="title"> Are the sounds of food/drink machines considered ‘Coin (dropping)’ sounds? class="content">

Not necessarily, only consider them ‘Coin (dropping)’ if the the sound of a coin dropping is audible. See the Description and consider choosing Present but not predominant if appropriate.

class="title"> Are the sounds of cash register considered ‘Coin (dropping)’ sounds? class="content">

Not necessarily, only consider them ‘Coin (dropping)’ if the the sound of a coin dropping is audible. See the Description and consider choosing Present but not predominant if appropriate.

class="title"> Are 'Keys jangling' sounds considered ‘Coin (dropping)’ sounds? class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Keys jangling' sounds from ‘Coin (dropping)’. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Coin (dropping)' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

class="title"> Are the sounds of spinning coins considered ‘Coin (dropping)’ sounds? class="content">

Yes, as the coin is bouncing on a hard surface (see Description).

/m/07rqsjt.faq:
class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Whoosh, swoosh, swish’ sounds?
class="content">

Only consider them ‘Whoosh, swoosh, swish’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not present. You can also check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are whistling wind sounds considered ‘Whoosh, swoosh, swish’ sounds? class="content">

Not necessarily, only if they are caused by a rigid object sweeping through the air.

class="title"> Are ‘Whoosh, swoosh, swish’ sounds containing impacts like 'Thump, thud' sounds considered Present and predominant sounds? class="content">

No. When ‘Whoosh, swoosh’ and impact sounds are both salient sources, please choose Present but not predominant.

/m/01b82r.faq:
class="title"> Are ‘Filing (rasp)’ or ‘ Sanding’ sounds considered 'Sawing' sounds?
class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Sawing' sounds from ‘Filing (rasp)’ or ‘Sanding’. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Sawing' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

class="title"> Are chainsaw or circular saw sounds considered ‘Sawing’ sounds? class="content">

Yes, as long as the sound is the result of cutting through a material (see Description).

class="title"> Are mathematical signals for educational or technological purposes considered ‘Sawing’ sounds? class="content">

No. You can also check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

/m/0c2wf.faq:
class="title"> Are the sounds of carriage return or bell produced by typewriters considered ‘Typewriter’ sounds?
class="content">

Yes, as long as they are produced by a typewriter. They are considered ‘Typewriter’ even if the sound does not contain any writing.

class="title"> Are 'Computer keyboard' sounds considered ‘Typewriter’ sounds? class="content">

No.

class="title"> Are sounds of electronic/electromechanical typewriters or Perkins Brailler considered ‘Typewriter’ sounds? class="content">

Yes, since they are operated by inputting text by pressing keys.

class="title"> Are sounds of teletypes considered ‘Typewriter’ sounds? class="content">

No, since the typing is not made by a human.

/m/01dwxx.faq:
class="title"> Are ‘Crow’ or 'Duck' sounds considered 'Gull, seagull' sounds?
class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Gull, seagull' sounds from ‘Crow’ or 'Duck'. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Gull, seagull' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples! You can also check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

/m/0838f.faq:
class="title"> Are sounds of water tap, washing machines or toilet flush considered 'Water' sounds?
class="content">

No. This category is more appropriate for sounds of water in natural contexts (see Hierarchy). Please check the Direct children for some good examples that fit in this category.

/m/07qrkrw.faq:
class="title"> Are human imitations considered meow sounds?
class="content">

Only consider them meow if they sound as real as an original one. Bad imitations should be rated as Not Present.

class="title"> Are growling, hiss or purr cat sounds considered meow sounds? class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish meow sounds from growling, hiss and purr. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish meow from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

/m/07rjwbb.faq:
class="title"> Are human imitations considered 'Onomatopoeia' > 'Hiss' sounds?
class="content">

Yes, since these phonetically imitate, resemble, or suggest the 'Hiss' sound.

class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Hiss’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Hiss’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not present.

class="title"> Are tape hiss sounds considered ‘Hiss’ sounds? class="content">

No, since it exists a better category for these kind of sounds: 'Background noise > Tape hiss'.

class="title"> Are vinyl needle sounds considered ‘Hiss’ sounds? class="content">

No, since it is not a fricative sound, such as from a cat giving warning, or an audience indicating disapproval (see Description).

/m/081rb.faq:
class="title"> Are typewriter, computer keyboard, or cell phone sounds considered ‘Writing’ sounds?
class="content">

No. The 'Typing' category is more appropriate for them.

class="title"> Are drawing, colouring or scribbling sounds considered ‘Writing’ sounds? class="content">

Yes.

class="title"> Are paper pages sounds considered ‘Writing’ sounds? class="content">

No. Only consider them ‘Writing’ if the writing sound is easy to recognize.

/m/01j3sz.faq:
class="title"> Are heavily processed sounds (e.g., distorted or with audio effects) considered ‘Laughter’ sounds?
class="content">

Only consider them ‘Laughter’ if the sounds are easy to recognize.

class="title"> Are 'Speech' or 'Applause' sounds considered 'Laughter'? class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Laughter' sounds from 'Speech' or 'Applause'. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Laughter' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples! If some of these similar categories are also salient in the audio sample, please choose Present but not predominant.

/m/02_nn.faq:
class="title"> Are human imitations considered ‘Fart’ sounds?
class="content">

Only consider them ‘Fart’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad imitations should be rated as Not present.

/m/09l8g.faq:
class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Human voice’ sounds?
class="content">

Only consider them ‘Human voice’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not Present.

class="title"> Are heavily processed sounds (e.g., distorted or with audio effects) considered ‘Human voice’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Human voice’ if the sounds are easy to recognize.

/m/07sr1lc.faq:
class="title"> Are all screams considered ‘Yell’ sounds?
class="content">

Not necessarily. Only consider them ‘Yell’ if there is verbal content present (that is, words can be easily recognized) and there is also an emotional connotation.

class="title"> Are all 'Shout' sounds considered ‘Yell’ sounds? class="content">

Not necessarily. This is somewhat subjective, but 'Yell' sounds usually have stronger emotional connotations, while 'Shout' sounds can encompass a more generic or pragmatic type of shouts.

class="title"> Are 'Bellow' sounds considered ‘Yell’ sounds? class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Yell' sounds from ‘Bellow’. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Yell' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

/m/01yrx.faq:
class="title"> Are human imitations considered ‘Cat’ sounds?
class="content">

Only consider them ‘Cat’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad imitations should be rated as Not present.

class="title"> Are cats walking or eating considered ‘Cat’ sounds? class="content">

Not necessarily, only consider it ‘Cat' if the sound is clearly associated with the category.

/m/0ltv.faq:
class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered 'Race car, auto racing' sounds?
class="content">

Only consider them 'Race car, auto racing' if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not Present.

class="title"> Are sounds of regular 'Cars passing by' or accelerating engines considered 'Race car, auto racing' sounds? class="content">

No. Regular cars and its related sounds belong to the 'Car' category and its children.

/m/0k4j.faq:
class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Car’ sounds?
class="content">

Only consider them ‘Car’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not present.

class="title"> Are heavily processed sounds (e.g., distorted or with audio effects) considered ‘Car’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Car’ if the sounds are easy to recognize.

class="title"> Are crashing cars, alarm, horn, siren, brake, seat belt and door sounds considered ‘Car’ sounds? class="content">

Yes, as long as the sound is associated with the category ‘Car’.

class="title"> Are ‘Truck’ and ‘Emergency vehicle’ sounds considered ‘Car’ sounds? class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Car' sounds from ‘Truck’ and ‘Emergency vehicle’. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Car' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

class="title"> Which is the difference between 'Traffic noise, roadway noise' sounds and ‘Car’ sounds? class="content">

Consider 'Traffic noise, roadway noise' when a lot of cars or vehicles are involved and 'Car' when its sound can be distinguish individually.

class="title"> What type of sounds are included in ‘Car’? class="content">

Remember to check the description and direct children to understand what type of sounds are considered 'Car’ sounds. You can also check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

/m/012f08.faq:
class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Motor vehicle (road)’ sounds?
class="content">

Only consider them ‘Motor vehicle (road)’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not present.

class="title"> Are heavily processed sounds (e.g., distorted or with audio effects) considered ‘Motor vehicle (road)’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Motor vehicle (road)’ if the sounds are easy to recognize.

class="title"> Are alarm, horn, siren, brake, seat belt and door sounds considered ‘Motor vehicle (road)’ class="content">

Yes, as long as the sound is associated with the category ‘Motor vehicle (road)’.

class="title"> Are ‘Boat, water vehicle’, ‘Aircraft’ and ‘Rail transport’ sounds considered ‘Motor vehicle (road)’? class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Motor vehicle (road)' sounds from ‘Boat, water vehicle’, ‘Aircraft’ and ‘Rail transport’. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Motor vehicle (road)' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

class="title"> Are engine or mechanism sounds considered ‘Motor vehicle (road)’ sounds? class="content">

Not necessarily, only consider them ‘Motor vehicle (road)’ if the sound is clearly associated with the category. To help you decide, you can check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> What type of sounds are included in ‘Motor vehicle (road)’? class="content">

Remember to check the description and direct children to understand what type of sounds are considered 'Motor vehicle (road)’ sounds. You can also check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

/m/07swgks.faq:
class="title"> Are human mouth gurgling sounds considered ‘Gurgling’ sounds?
class="content">

No.

class="title"> Are filling with a liquid sounds considered ‘Gurgling’ sounds? class="content">

Not necessarily, only consider them ‘Gurgling’ if the bubbling sound is audible.

class="title"> Are domestic sounds (e.g., sounds from bottles or sinks) or other non-natural sounds considered ‘Gurgling’? class="content">

Yes, as long as they contain the bubbling sound of water flowing through a narrow constriction. In this category, non-natural sounds that comply with the Description are accepted (even though this is not fully consistent with the Hierarchy).

/m/015p6.faq:
class="title"> Are domesticated bird sounds (e.g., chicken or rooster duck) considered ‘Bird’ sounds?
class="content">

No, since the 'Bird' category only considers wild animals (see hierarchy).

class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Bird’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Bird’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not present.

class="title"> Are human imitations considered ‘Bird’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Bird’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad imitations should be rated as Not present.

/m/0jbk.faq:
class="title"> Are human imitations considered ‘Animal’ sounds?
class="content">

Only consider them ‘Animal’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad imitations should be rated as Not present.

/m/02_41.faq:
class="title"> Are lighter sounds or sounds of striking matches considered 'Fire' sounds?
class="content">

Not necessarily, only consider them 'Fire' if the sound of the flame is audible. If the sound of fire is present, as well as the click of the lighter or the striking match, please choose Present but not predominant.

class="title"> Are fireworks or explosions sounds considered 'Fire' sounds? class="content">

Not necessarily, only consider them 'Fire' if the fire sound is audible.

class="title"> Are gas and stove sounds considered 'Fire' sounds? class="content">

Yes, as long as the generated flame is audible.

/m/034srq.faq:
class="title"> Are ‘Stream’ or ‘Water fall’ sounds considered 'Waves, surf' sounds?
class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Waves, surf' sounds from ‘Stream’ and ‘Water fall’. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Waves, surf' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples! You can also check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Waves, surf’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Waves, surf’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not present.

class="title"> Are lake waves sounds considered ‘Waves, surf’ sounds? class="content">

Yes, as long as the waves are audible.

/m/02hnl.faq:
class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Drum kit’ sounds?
class="content">

Yes, as long as they sound similar to a real ‘Drum kit’.

class="title"> Are single drum set sounds considered ‘Drum kit’ sounds? class="content">

No.

class="title"> Are beatbox sounds considered ‘Drum kit’ sounds? class="content">

No, since it exists a category for beatbox sounds.

/m/07rgt08.faq:
class="title"> Are ‘Snicker’, ‘Belly laugh’, 'Giggle' or ‘Baby laughter’ sounds considered 'Chuckle, chortle' sounds?
class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Chuckle, chortle' sounds from ‘Snicker’, ‘Belly laugh’, 'Giggle' and ‘Baby laughter’. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Chuckle, chortle' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples! If some of these similar categories are also salient in the audio sample, please choose Present but not predominant.

class="title"> Are ‘Baby laughter’ sounds considered 'Chuckle, chortle' sounds? class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Chuckle, chortle' sounds from ‘Baby laughter’. Laughter produced by a baby or infant must fall only under the ‘Baby laughter’ category. Therefore, please choose Not present.

/m/023pjk.faq:
class="title"> Are ‘Dishes, pots, and pans' sounds considered 'Cutlery, silverware' sounds?
class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Cutlery, silverware’ sounds from ‘Dishes, pots, and pans'. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Cutlery, silverware' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

class="title"> Are the sounds of hitting cutlery against dishes or glasses considered 'Cutlery, silverware' sounds? class="content">

Not necessarily. If the predominant sound comes from the dish or glass, there are other categories more appropriate for this sound, like ‘Dishes, pots, and pans' for example.

class="title"> Are sounds of drawers carrying cutlery inside considered 'Cutlery, silverware' sounds? class="content">

Yes, as long as the sound of cutlery is audible. Consider choosing Present but not predominant if the sound of both the drawer and the cutlery are salient.

/m/0dxrf.faq:
class="title"> Are sounds of pots, pans or cutlery considered ‘Frying (food)’ sounds?
class="content">

Not necessarily, only consider them ‘Frying (food)’ if the sound of food being cooked in oil or another fat is audible. If both type of sounds occur, please consider choosing Present but not predominant.

/m/05r5wn.faq:
class="title"> Are rattling sounds produced by objects other than the instrument Rattle considered ‘Rattle (instrument)’ sounds?
class="content">

No. There is another category more appropriate for these sounds: 'Rattle'. 'Rattle' encompasses rapid series of short loud sounds as of small hard items loose inside a container, which are produced by other objects that are not musical instruments.

/m/07qqyl4.faq:
class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Boom’ sounds?
class="content">

Only consider them ‘Boom’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not present.

class="title"> Are ‘Gunshot, gunfire', 'Fireworks' or 'Burst, pop’ sounds considered 'Boom' sounds? class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Boom' sounds from ‘Gunshot, gunfire', 'Fireworks' and 'Burst, pop’. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Boom' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples! You can also check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

/m/02mk9.faq:
class="title"> Is anything (like vehicles or home appliances) with an audible engine considered ‘Engine’ sounds?
class="content">

Yes, as long as the 'Engine' is audible.

class="title"> Are traffic sounds considered ‘Engine’ sounds? class="content">

Yes, as long as the engine sound is audible. Consider choosing Present but not predominant if necessary.

class="title"> Are machines without audible engine or 'Mechanisms' considered ‘Engine’ sounds? class="content">

No. You can also check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are engines without motion sounds as those from vehicles like tires, breaks or friction sounds considered ‘Engine’ sounds? class="content">

No, as long as there is no audible engine.

/t/dd00134.faq:
class="title"> Are stopped vehicle sounds considered 'Car passing by' sounds?
class="content">

No, you should consider them 'Car passing by' if a vehicle is passing by.

class="title"> Are traffic sounds considered 'Car passing by' sounds? class="content">

Only consider them 'Car passing by' if you can easily hear one car or two passing by. When ‘Car passing by’ and traffic are both salient sounds, please choose Present but not predominant.

class="title"> Are 'Car passing by’ sounds containing ‘Vehicle horn, car horn, honking’ or siren sounds considered Present and predominant? class="content">

No, when ‘Car passing by’, ‘Vehicle horn, car horn, honking’ or siren are all salient sources, please choose Present but not predominant.

class="title"> Are 'Race car, auto racing’ sounds considered ‘Car passing by’? class="content">

Yes, as long as the car passes by. In this particular case, 'Race car, auto racing’ sounds should be accepted in both categories as they have partial overlap.

class="title"> Are sounds of trucks passing by considered 'Car passing by'? class="content">

No, only sounds generated by cars are accepted here. Trucks passing by belong to the 'Truck' category.

/m/0k5j.faq:
class="title"> Are radio communications or cabin crew announcements considered ‘Aircraft’ sounds?
class="content">

Yes, as long as they come from the inside of an 'Aircraft'. You can also check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Aircraft’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Aircraft’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not present.

class="title"> Are plane models or drones considered ‘Aircraft’ sounds? class="content">

No.

/m/07gql.faq:
class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Trumpet’ sounds?
class="content">

Only consider them ‘Trumpet' if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not present.

class="title"> Are 'French horn', 'Trombone', 'Bugle' or 'Cornet' sounds considered 'Trumpet' sounds? class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Trumpet' sounds from 'French horn', 'Trombone', 'Bugle' and 'Cornet'. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Trumpet' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples! You can also check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are wah-wah (Harmon) sounds considered ‘Trumpet’ sounds? class="content">

Yes, since the sound is generated by a (muted) trumpet.

/m/07r5v4s.faq:
class="title"> Are 'Pour', 'Fill (with liquid)' and 'Splash, splatter' sounds considered ‘Drip’ sounds?
class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Drip' sounds from 'Pour', 'Fill (with liquid)' and 'Splash, splatter'. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Drip' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

class="title"> Are dribble, trickle sounds considered ‘Drip’ sounds? class="content">

No. Consider 'Drip' sounds when you hear liquid drops falling down one by one, separatedly. Dribble, trickle happens when a liquid is flowing slowly in an unsteady stream or drops. When ‘Drip’ and dribble, trickle are both salient sounds, please choose Present but not predominant.

class="title"> Is a single drop sound considered ‘Drip’ sound? class="content">

Yes.

/t/dd00003.faq:
class="title"> Are choir sounds considered 'Male singing' sounds?
class="content">

Not necessarily, only consider them 'Male singing' if you hear at least one male singing.

class="title"> Are male kids singing considered 'Male singing' sounds? class="content">

Only consider them 'Male singing' if the sound is generated by an adult human male.

class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered 'Male singing' sounds? class="content">

Only consider them 'Male singing' if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not Present.

class="title"> Are heavily processed sounds (e.g., distorted or with audio effects) considered 'Male singing' sounds? class="content">

Only consider them 'Male singing' if the sounds are easy to recognize.

/t/dd00004.faq:
class="title"> Are choir sounds considered 'Female singing' sounds?
class="content">

Not necessarily, only consider them 'Female singing' if you hear at least one female singing.

class="title"> Are female kids singing considered 'Female singing' sounds? class="content">

Only consider them 'Female singing' if the sound is generated by an adult human female.

class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered 'Female singing' sounds? class="content">

Only consider them 'Female singing' if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not Present.

class="title"> Are heavily processed sounds (e.g., distorted or with audio effects) considered 'Female singing' sounds? class="content">

Only consider them 'Female singing' if the sounds are easy to recognize.

/m/07q6cd_.faq:
class="title"> Are screechy sounds considered 'Squeak' sounds?
class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Squeak' sounds from 'Screech'. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Squeal' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

class="title"> Are 'Squeal' sounds considered 'Squeak' sounds? class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Squeak' sounds from 'Squeal'. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Squeak' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

class="title"> How should I rate the sound of a Door squeaking that is eventually closed? class="content">

Present but not predominant.

class="title"> Are squeaky sounds generated by plastic objects considered 'Squeak' sounds? class="content">

Yes, as long as they are short, high-pitched noises without a sharp attack.

class="title"> Are squeaky sounds generated by animals considered 'Squeak' sounds? class="content">

Yes, as long as they are short, high-pitched noises without a sharp attack.

class="title"> What are typical examples of 'Squeak' sounds? class="content">

Some typical 'Squeak' sounds come from wooden doors, door hinges, rubbing rubber surfaces or balloons (but other sources can also produce 'Squeak' sounds).

class="title"> Are rumbling stomach noises considered 'Squeak' sounds? class="content">

No.

/m/04s8yn.faq:
class="title"> Are ‘Gull, seagull’ sounds considered 'Crow' sounds?
class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Crow' sounds from ‘Gull, seagull’. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Crow' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples! You can also check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are human imitations considered ‘Crow’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Crow’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad imitations should be rated as Not present.

/m/01lsmm.faq:
class="title"> Are ‘Scissors’ sounds containing paper pages or cardboard sounds considered Present and predominant sounds?
class="content">

No, when the paper pages or cardboard, and ‘Scissors’ are both salient sources, please choose Present but not predominant.

/m/04brg2.faq:
class="title"> Are 'Cutlery, silverware' sounds considered 'Dishes, pots, pans' sounds?
class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish them. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Dishes, pots, pans' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

class="title"> Are washing dishes sounds considered Present and predominant sounds? class="content">

No, when the sound of washing, and ‘Dishes, pots, and pans’ are both salient sources, please choose Present but not predominant.

class="title"> Are sounds of cutlery hitting dishes, pots and pans considered 'Dishes, pots, pans' sounds? class="content">

Yes, as long as the predominant sound comes from the dish, pot or pan.

class="title"> Are atypical uses of the dishes, pots, and pans considered ‘Dishes, pots, and pans’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Dishes, pots, and pans’ if the source is easy to recognize.

class="title"> Are kitchen cup sounds considered ‘Dishes, pots, and pans’ sounds? class="content">

Yes, see the Description.

/m/0j6m2.faq:
class="title"> Are water tap and faucet sounds considered 'Stream' sounds?
class="content">

No. To help you decide, you can check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

/m/07rn7sz.faq:
class="title"> Are the sounds of throwing away glass objects without breaking considered ‘Shatter’ sounds?
class="content">

No. Only consider them ‘Shatter’ if the sound of the glass breaking is audible.

class="title"> Are ‘Shatter’ sounds containing explosions considered Present and predominant sounds? class="content">

No. When ‘Shatter' and explosion sounds are both salient sounds, please choose Present but not predominant.

class="title"> Are pottery sounds like tea cups, mugs or plates considered ‘Shatter’ sounds? class="content">

Yes, as long as they contain 'Shatter' sounds. The Description and the breaking sound of 'Shatter' prevail over the 'Glass' category.

/m/039jq.faq:
class="title"> Are filling a glass (with liquid) sounds considered ‘Glass’ sounds?
class="content">

No, since it exists a better category for these kind of sounds: 'Fill (with liquid)’'.

class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Glass’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Glass’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not present.

class="title"> Are glass singing fingers (rubbing the rim of a glass) considered ‘Glass’ sound? class="content">

Yes.

class="title"> Are metal objects like keys, coins, cutlery hitting a glass surface considered ‘Glass’ sounds? class="content">

Only if 'Glass' is audible. When ‘Glass’ and metallic sounds are both salient sounds, please choose Present but not predominant.

/m/02rtxlg.faq:
class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Whispering’ sounds?
class="content">

Only consider them ‘Whispering’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not present.

/m/07pbtc8.faq:
class="title"> Are ‘Run’ or ‘Shuffle’ sounds considered 'Walk, footsteps' sounds?
class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Walk, footsteps' sounds from ‘Run’ or ‘Shuffle’. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Walk, footsteps' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Walk, footsteps’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Walk, footsteps’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not present.

class="title"> Are sounds of climbing/going down stairs considered ‘Walk, footsteps’ sounds? class="content">

Yes.

class="title"> Are heavily processed sounds (e.g., distorted or with audio effects) considered ‘Walk, footsteps’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Walk, footsteps’ if the sounds are easy to recognize.

/m/028ght.faq:
class="title"> Are ‘Applause’ sounds containing ‘Cheering’ sounds considered Present and predominant sounds?
class="content">

No, when ‘Applause’ and ‘Cheering’ are both salient sources, please choose Present but not predominant

class="title"> Are 'Clapping' sounds considered ‘Applause’ sounds? class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Applause' sounds from 'Clapping' ones. Click on Clapping to check its description and examples!

class="title"> Are rhythmic clapping sounds considered ‘Applause’ sounds? class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Applause' sounds from 'Clapping' ones. Click on Clapping to check its description and examples!

class="title"> Are heavily processed sounds (e.g., distorted or with audio effects) considered ‘Applause’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Applause’ if the sounds are easy to recognize.

/m/02yds9.faq:
class="title"> Are human imitations considered 'Purr' sounds?
class="content">

Only consider them 'Purr' if they sound as real as an original one. Bad imitations should be rated as Not Present.

class="title"> Are growling, hiss or meow cat sounds considered 'Purr' sounds? class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Purr' sounds from growling, hiss or meow. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Purr' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

/m/02x984l.faq:
class="title"> Are ‘Air conditioning’ or ‘Gears’ sounds considered 'Mechanical fan' sounds?
class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Mechanical fan' sounds from ‘Air conditioning’ or ‘Gears’. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Mechanical fan' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples! You can also check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are ‘Mechanical fan’ sounds containing ‘Air conditioning’ or 'Engine' sounds considered Present and predominant sounds? class="content">

No. When ‘Mechanical fan’ and ‘Air conditioning’ or 'Engine' are both salient sources, please choose Present but not predominant.

class="title"> Are air extractors from kitchens or bathrooms considered 'Mechanical fan' sounds? class="content">

Yes, as long as they take air in (instead of expelling it out) via the motion of a rotating arrangement of vanes or blades. Please, do not confound these sounds with 'Air conditioning' sounds. You can also check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

/t/dd00112.faq:
class="title"> Are rustling sounds considered ‘Crumpling, crinkling’ sounds?
class="content">

Not necessarily, since it exist another category for these sounds: Source-ambiguous sounds > Onomatopoeia > Rustle.

class="title"> Are ‘Crushing’ sounds like those made to bottles of water or soda cans considered 'Crumpling, crinkling' sounds? class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Crumpling, crinkling' sounds from ‘Crushing’. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Crumplign, crinkling' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

/m/0dv5r.faq:
class="title"> Are the sounds of flash loading, zoom, opening the film door, or other sounds produced by camera considered ‘Camera’ sounds?
class="content">

Yes, as long as they identify a camera as the source.

class="title"> Are digital beepings and melodies from new digital cameras considered ‘Camera’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Camera’ sounds if those beepings and melodies are easy to relate with any 'Camera'.

/m/09b5t.faq:
class="title"> Are ‘Crowing, cock-a-doodle-doo’ or 'Cluck' sounds considered ‘Chicken, rooster’ sounds?
class="content">

Yes, as long as the sound is associated with the category ‘Chicken, rooster’.

class="title"> Are chick sounds (i.e., chicken or rooster babies) considered ‘Chicken, rooster’ sounds? class="content">

Yes, they are ‘Chicken, rooster’ sounds, even though they may sound similar to certain birds. To be sure of what they are, you can check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are fowls walking considered ‘Chicken, rooster’ sounds? class="content">

Not necessarily, only consider it ‘Chicken, rooster’ if the sound is clearly associated with the category.

/m/053hz1.faq:
class="title"> Are ‘Cheering’ sounds containing ‘Applause’ sounds considered Present and predominant sounds?
class="content">

No, when ‘Cheering’ and ‘Applause’ are both salient sources, please choose Present but not predominant. Note that ‘Cheering’ refers strictly to human vocalizations while 'Applause' is the collective act of clapping by a group (with the hands).

/m/05kq4.faq:
class="title"> Are ‘Stream’ or ‘Water fall’ sounds considered 'Ocean' sounds?
class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Ocean' sounds from ‘Stream’ and ‘Water fall’. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Ocean' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples! You can also check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

/t/dd00130.faq:
class="title"> Are 'Idling' sounds considered 'Engine starting' sounds?
class="content">

Yes, as long as the 'Idling' is short and the natural outcome of starting the engine. If that is not the case, please choose Present but not predominant.

class="title"> Are ‘Accelerating, revving, vroom' or shutting off sounds considered 'Engine starting' sounds? class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Engine starting' sounds from them. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Engine starting' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples! If several types of engine sounds coincide, please choose Present but not predominant.

/m/01hgjl.faq:
class="title"> Are human imitations considered ‘Scratching’ sounds?
class="content">

Only consider them ‘Scratching’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad imitations should be rated as Not present.

class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Scratching (performance technique)’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Scratching (performance technique)’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not present. If 'Scratching (performance technique)' and other musical elements are involved, please choose Present but not predominant.

class="title"> Are ‘Scratching (performance technique)’ sounds mixed with other sound tracks considered Present and predominant sounds? class="content">

No. When ‘Scratching (performance technique)’ and other sound tracks are both salient sounds, please choose Present but not predominant.

/m/06_fw.faq:
class="title"> Are BMX bike or scooter sounds considered ‘Skateboard’ sounds?
class="content">

No.

/m/083vt.faq:
class="title"> Are squeaky wooden doors considered 'Wood' sounds?
class="content">

No, because the squeak sound usually comes from the metallic hinge of the door, and not from the door itself. If wooden door and squeak are both salient sounds, please choose Present but not predominant. An example is shown in this link.

/m/07rrlb6.faq:
class="title"> Which kind of liquid sounds are considered ‘Splash, splatter’ sounds?
class="content">

Any audible impact between a liquid and a hard surface and vice versa. For example, a stone thrown into a mass of water, or a mass of water thrown into the floor. See the provided examples. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Splash, splatter' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

class="title"> Are 'Pour', 'Fill (with liquid)', dripping or water tap sounds considered ‘Splash, splatter’ sounds? class="content">

Not necessarily. 'Splash, splatter' must be used only when the impact or collision sound is audible. When ‘Splash, splatter’ and 'Pour', 'Fill (with liquid)', dripping or water tap are all salient sounds, please choose Present but not predominant.

/m/0l15bq.faq:
class="title"> Are 'Applause' sounds considered ‘Clapping’ sounds?
class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Applause' sounds from 'Clapping' ones. 'Applause' sounds are an expression of approval by the collective act of clapping by a group. Please note that 'Clapping' can also be a group action. Click on Applause to check its description and examples!

class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Clapping’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Clapping’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not present.

class="title"> Are 'Finger snapping' sounds considered 'Clapping' sounds? class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Clapping' sounds from 'Finger snapping' ones. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Clapping' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

class="title"> Are heavily processed sounds (e.g., distorted or with audio effects) considered ‘Clapping’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Clapping’ if the sounds are easy to recognize. If the clapping sound is recognizable but is accompanied by audio effects, e.g. reverb, please choose Present but not predominant.

/m/0239kh.faq:
class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Cowbell’ sounds?
class="content">

Only consider them ‘Cowbell’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not present.

/m/03vt0.faq:
class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Insect’ sounds?
class="content">

Only consider them ‘Insect’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not present.

/m/042v_gx.faq:
class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Acoustic guitar’ sounds?
class="content">

Only consider them ‘Acoustic guitar’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not present.

class="title"> Are heavily processed sounds (e.g., distorted or with audio effects) considered ‘Acoustic guitar’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Acoustic guitar’ if the sounds are easy to recognize.

class="title"> Are atypical uses of the acoustic guitar (e.g., use it as a percussion instrument) considered ‘Acoustic Guitar’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Acoustic Guitar’ if the source is easy to recognize.

/m/0dwsp.faq:
class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered 'Marimba, xylophone' sounds?
class="content">

Only consider them 'Marimba, xylophone' if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not present.

class="title"> Are 'Glockenspiel', 'Vibraphone' or metallophone sounds considered 'Marimba, xylophone' sounds? class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Marimba, xylophone' sounds from 'Glockenspiel', 'Vibraphone' and metallophone. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Marimba, xylophone' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

/m/01m2v.faq:
class="title"> Are old computer keyboard sounds considered 'Computer keyboard'?
class="content">

Yes. Some old computer keyboards can actually sound similar to a 'Typewriter'. If you're doubting, you can check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are mouse clicks considered ‘Computer keyboard’ sounds? class="content">

No. If mouse clicking sounds and 'Computer keyboard' sounds are both salient, please choose 'Present but not predominant'.

/m/0342h.faq:
class="title"> Are atypical uses of the guitar considered ‘Guitar’ sounds?
class="content">

Only consider them ‘Guitar’ if the source is easy to recognize.

class="title"> Are sounds of guitars with pedals or distortion effects considered ‘Guitar’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Guitar’ if the guitar is easy to recognize. That is, if the effects are typically used with guitars.

/m/07rjzl8.faq:
class="title"> Are 'Squeak' sounds considered 'Slam' sounds?
class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Slam' sounds from ‘Squeak’. Understanding the siblings will help you distinguish 'Slam' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples! If both slam and squeak sounds are salient sources, please choose Present but not predominant.

class="title"> Are sounds of door being (un)locked or door handle considered 'Slam' sounds? class="content">

No, 'Slam' refers to the fact of closing a door violently. If additional sounds occur, please choose Present but not predominant.

class="title"> Are sounds of door being opened considered 'Slam' sounds? class="content">

No, 'Slam' refers to the fact of closing a door violently. If the door is also being opened, please choose Present but not predominant.

class="title"> How violent must the door slam be in order to consider it 'Slam'? class="content">

Just a little bit violent is enough for a sound to be consider door 'Slam' (considering that there is no other category for standard door closing). However, sound of doors being closed slowly and quietly must be rated as Not Present. You can check the provided examples to get an idea.

class="title"> Are you not sure what to decide with single impact sounds? class="content">

You can check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

/m/0ytgt.faq:
class="title"> Are 'Babbling' sounds considered ‘Child speech, kid speaking’ sounds?
class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Child speech, kid speaking' sounds from 'Babbling’. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Child speech, kid speaking' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

class="title"> Are any child sounds (e.g.: baby laughter, singing or screaming) considered ‘Child speech, kid speaking’ sounds? class="content">

No, since it is not a speech sound (see hierarchy). For example, 'Child singing' sounds should be rated as Not present since it exists another category for these sounds.

class="title"> Are whispering sounds considered 'Child speech, kid speaking' sounds? class="content">

No, since it exists a category for that concept: Human sounds > Human voice > Whispering.

/m/07pp_mv.faq:
class="title"> Which kind of alarms should be considered ‘Alarm’ sounds?
class="content">

Any kind of alarm that conveys warning of danger (for example sirens, horns, whistles, smoke detectors, fire alarms, car alarm), but also notifications and alerts (for example alarm clocks, telephones, doorbells). You can check the Direct children of 'Alarm' to see typical examples.

class="title"> Are videogame sounds considered ‘Alarm’ sounds? class="content">

Not necessarily, only if they warn of danger or alert. If you doubt, you can check the direct children of 'Alarm' to see typical examples.

class="title"> Are computer-generated notification sounds considered ‘Alarm’ sounds? class="content">

Yes, for example short tones to call attention like those that are sometimes generated by mobile phones.

/m/01p970.faq:
class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Tabla’ sounds?
class="content">

Only consider them ‘Tabla’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not present.

/m/085jw.faq:
class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Wind instrument, woodwind instrument’ sounds?
class="content">

Only consider them ‘Wind instrument, woodwind instrument’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not present.

class="title"> Are heavily processed sounds (e.g., distorted or with audio effects) considered ‘Wind instrument, woodwind instrument’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Wind instrument, woodwind instrument’ if the sounds are easy to recognize.

class="title"> Are ‘Brass instrument’, ‘Accordion’ and 'Didgeridoo' sounds considered ‘Wind instrument, woodwind instrument’? class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Wind instrument, woodwind instrument' sounds from ‘Brass instrument’, ‘Accordion’ and 'Didgeridoo'. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Wind instrument, woodwind instrument' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

/m/0gy1t2s.faq:
class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Bicycle bell’ sounds?
class="content">

Only consider them ‘Bicycle bell’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not present.

/m/07qcpgn.faq:
class="title"> Are door knocks or sounds produced with the knuckles of the hand considered 'Tap' sounds?
class="content">

No, the 'Knock' category is more appropriate for those. Understanding the siblings will help you distinguish 'Tap' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

class="title"> Are loud tap sounds still considered 'Tap' sounds? class="content">

No, only consider them ‘Tap’ if the tap sound comes from a light collision.

class="title"> Are you not sure what to decide with single impact sounds? class="content">

You can check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

/m/0mkg.faq:
class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Accordion’ sounds?
class="content">

Only consider them ‘Accordion’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not present.

class="title"> Are heavily processed sounds (e.g., distorted or with audio effects) considered ‘Accordion’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Accordion’ if the sounds are easy to recognize.

class="title"> Are accordion breathing sounds considered ‘Accordion’ sounds? class="content">

No, only consider them ‘Accordion’ if an accordion note is audible.

/m/0mbct.faq:
class="title"> Are heavily processed sounds (e.g., distorted or with audio effects) considered ‘Gong’ sounds?
class="content">

Only consider them ‘Gong’ if the sounds are easy to recognize.

/m/01b_21.faq:
class="title"> Are ‘Sniff’ or ‘Sneeze’ sounds considered 'Cough' sounds?
class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Cough' sounds from ‘Sniff’ or ‘Sneeze’. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Cough' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

/m/015lz1.faq:
class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Singing’ sounds?
class="content">

Only consider them ‘Singing’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not present.

class="title"> Are heavily processed sounds (e.g., distorted or with audio effects) considered ‘Singing’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Singing’ if the sounds are easy to recognize.

/m/01hnzm.faq:
class="title"> Are any kind of melodies considered 'Ringtone' sounds?
class="content">

Not necessarily. Only consider them 'Ringtone' sounds if they evoque the sensation of a ringtone. For example, simple, not very long repetitive melodies. You can also check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are 'Telephone bell ringing' sounds considered 'Ringtone' sounds? class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Ringtone' sounds from 'Telephone bell ringing'. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Ringtone' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples! You can also check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are incoming text message sounds considered 'Ringtone' sounds? class="content">

Yes. See Description and also note that they can be quite short. To help you decide, you can check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

/m/07qn4z3.faq:
class="title"> Are non-animal 'rapid series of short loud sounds as of small hard items loose inside a container' considered ‘Rattle’ sounds?
class="content">

Yes, since one of its parents is 'Onomatopoeia' (see its definition).

class="title"> Are musical instruments considered ‘Rattle’ sounds? class="content">

No, since there is another category more appropriate for these sounds: 'Rattle (instrument)'. Also note that rain-sticks are musical instruments, therefore these should be voted as Not present.

/m/03w41f.faq:
class="title"> Are tubular bell sounds considered ‘Church bell’ sounds?
class="content">

No. To help you decide, you can check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

/m/07qs1cx.faq:
class="title"> Are ‘Chop’, ‘Splinter’ or ‘Snap’ sounds considered 'Crack' sounds?
class="content">

Not necessarily, be sure to distinguish 'Crack' sounds from ‘Chop’, ‘Splinter’ or ‘Snap’. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Crack' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples! You can also check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are human imitations considered ‘Crack’ sounds? class="content">

Yes, as far as they phonetically imitate, resemble, or suggest the ‘Crack’ sound (see the 'Onomatopoeia' description).

class="title"> Are ‘Splinter’ sounds containing ‘Crack’ sounds considered Present and predominant sounds? class="content">

No. When ‘Splinter’ and ‘Crack’ are both salient sources, please choose Present but not predominant.

class="title"> Are crashing glass sounds considered ‘Crack’ sounds? class="content">

No, since it exists a better category for these kind of sounds: 'Smash, crash’'.

/m/09xqv.faq:
class="title"> Are human imitations considered ‘Cricket’ sounds?
class="content">

Only consider them ‘Cricket’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad imitations should be rated as Not present.

class="title"> Are cicada or grasshopper sounds considered ‘Cricket’ sounds? class="content">

No, since they are different species. To be sure that it is a cricket sound, you can check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

/m/0k65p.faq:
class="title"> Are hands interacting with other objects sounds considered ‘Hands’ sounds?
class="content">

Not necessarily, only consider them ‘Hands’ if the sound originates primarily from hands or fingers.

class="title"> Are washing hands and rubbing hands sounds considered ‘Hands’ sounds? class="content">

Yes, since these sounds originate primarily from hands or fingers.

class="title"> Are slap sounds considered ‘Hands’ sounds? class="content">

No, since it exists a better category for these kind of sounds: 'Generic impact sounds > Slap, smack'.

class="title"> Are cracking knuckles sounds considered ‘Hands’ sounds? class="content">

Yes, since it originates primarily from the hands and fingers of humans (see Description).

/m/013y1f.faq:
class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Organ’ sounds?
class="content">

Only consider them ‘Organ’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not present.

class="title"> Are heavily processed sounds (e.g., distorted or with audio effects) considered ‘Organ’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Organ’ if the sounds are easy to recognize.

/m/03v3yw.faq:
class="title"> Are the sounds of keys dropping on a surface considered ‘Keys jangling’ sounds?
class="content">

Yes, as long as the sound of the keys jangling is audible.

class="title"> Are the sounds of keys jangling along with other door related sounds (like opening a lock) considered ‘Keys jangling’ sounds? class="content">

Yes, as long as the sound of the keys jangling is audible. In this case please choose Present but not predominant.

class="title"> Are ‘Coin (dropping)’ sounds considered 'Keys jangling' sounds? class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Keys jangling' sounds from ‘Coin (dropping)’. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Keys jangling' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

/m/07q7njn.faq:
class="title"> Are 'Shatter' sounds considered ‘Chink, clink’ sounds?
class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish ‘Chink, clink’ from 'Shatter' sounds. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

class="title"> Are metallic sounds considered ‘Chink, clink’ sounds? class="content">

Yes (see the Description). In this particular case, the category 'Chink, clink' prevails over the 'Glass' category.

class="title"> Are pottery sounds like tea cups, mugs or plates considered ‘Chink, clink’ sounds? class="content">

Yes, the category 'Chink, clink' prevails over the 'Glass' category. You can also check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

/m/01d380.faq:
class="title"> Are jackhammer or metal grinder sounds considered ‘Drill’ sounds?
class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Jackhammer' or metal grinder sounds from ‘Drill’ ones. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Drill' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples! You can also check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are screwdriver sounds considered ‘Drill’ sounds? class="content">

No, as far as a screwdriver is a hand tool for tightening or loosening a screw, not for making holes as a ‘Drill’ does. You can also check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

/m/0912c9.faq:
class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Vehicle horn, car horn, honking’ sounds?
class="content">

Only consider them ‘Vehicle horn, car horn, honking’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not present.

class="title"> Are heavily processed sounds (e.g., distorted or with audio effects) considered ‘Vehicle horn, car horn, honking’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Vehicle horn, car horn, honking’ if the sounds are easy to recognize.

class="title"> Are ‘Vehicle horn, car horn, honking’ sounds containing 'Car passing by’ sounds or, in general, any engine sounds considered Present and predominant? class="content">

No. When ‘Vehicle horn, car horn, honking’ and engine sounds are both salient sources, please choose Present but not predominant.

class="title"> Are 'Air horn, truck horn' sounds considered 'Vehicle horn, car horn, honking' sounds? class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Vehicle horn, car horn, honking' sounds from 'Air horn, truck horn'. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Vehicle horn, car horn, honking' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

class="title"> Are train horn sounds considered 'Vehicle horn, car horn, honking' sounds? class="content">

No. There is another category 'Train horn' that is more appropriate for them.

/m/0ghcn6.faq:
class="title"> Are any kind of growling sounds considered ‘Growling’ sounds?
class="content">

Not necessarily, only consider them ‘Growling’ if they sound like animal growling.

/m/07pzfmf.faq:
class="title"> What are the typical sound sources that produce 'Crackle' sounds?
class="content">

The most typical case is the little explosions that sometimes occur in a fireplace. Another typical case is the sound generated when reproducing a vinyl that has a certain amount of dust. However, please be aware that other sources can also be valid for 'Crackle'. To help you decide, you can check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are sounds of cracking or breaking wood, or sizzle sounds considered 'Crackle' sounds? class="content">

No. Please check the Description. To help you decide, you can check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

/m/0bt9lr.faq:
class="title"> Are all typical dog sounds (apart from the listed children) considered 'Dog’ sounds?
class="content">

Yes, as long as they are easy to recognize.

class="title"> Are dogs walking or eating considered ‘Dog’ sounds? class="content">

Not necessarily, only consider it ‘Dog’ if the sound is clearly associated with the category.

/m/03cczk.faq:
class="title"> Are ‘Biting’ sounds considered ‘Chewing, mastication’ sounds?
class="content">

No. Be sure to distinguish ‘Chewing, mastication’ sounds from ‘Biting’. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish ‘Chewing, mastication’ from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples! Usually, biting refers to tearing a piece of food with the teeth and it is the first action in the process of eating. On the contrary, chewing/mastication refers to a subsequent process by which food is repeatedly crushed and ground by teeth (typically with the mouth shut). If both ‘Chewing, mastication’ and ‘Biting' are salient sources, please choose Present but not predominant.

class="title"> Are animals chewing or masticating considered ‘Chewing, mastication’ sounds? class="content">

No, since this category is only for human sounds (see Hierarchy).

class="title"> Are heavily processed sounds (e.g., distorted or with audio effects) considered ‘Chewing, mastication’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Chewing, mastication’ if the sounds are easy to recognize.

/m/0195fx.faq:
class="title"> Are ‘Subway, metro, underground’ sounds containing chattering sounds or next stop announcements considered Present and predominant?
class="content">

Yes. Recordings made inside 'Subway, metro, underground' that contain the typical sounds found in the interior of those transports are considered Present and predominant. If there is clear salient conversation, please choose Present but not predominant.

class="title"> Are ‘Train’ sounds considered 'Subway, metro, underground’ sounds? class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish ‘Subway, metro, underground’ sounds from 'Train'. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Subway, metro, underground' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

/m/07qnq_y.faq:
class="title"> Are sounds as the impact of an 'Arrow' or dart considered ‘Thump, thud’ sounds?
class="content">

Yes.

class="title"> Are 'Whoosh, swoosh, swish' considered ‘Thump, thud’ sounds? class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Thump, thud' sounds from ‘Whoosh, swoosh, swish’. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Thump, thud' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

class="title"> What type of sounds are included in ‘Thump, thud’? class="content">

Think of the sound of a dart impacting on the dartboard, or a heavy book dropped to the floor. Those are dry sounds, usually without reverb or echo. To help you decide, you can check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

/m/07qcx4z.faq:
class="title"> Are packing tape or duct tape sounds considered ‘Tearing’ sounds?
class="content">

Not necessarily. There is a category more suited for these kind of sounds: 'Sounds of things > Domestic sounds, home sounds > Packing tape, duct tape'. However, if the tape is ripped (which happens often after it is unpeeled), that is considered a 'Tearing' sound. In this case, please choose Present but not predominant. In case of doubt, you can check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are velcro sounds considered ‘Tearing’ sounds? class="content">

No, since it exists a better category for these kind of sounds: 'Sounds of things > Domestic sounds, home sounds > Velcro, hook and loop fastener'. In case of doubt, you can also check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are ‘Crushing’ or ‘Crumpling, crinkling’ sounds considered 'Tearing' sounds? class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Tearing' sounds from ‘Crushing’ and ‘Crumpling, crinkling’. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Tearing' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples! You can also check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

/m/07plct2.faq:
class="title"> Are ‘Tearing’ or ‘Crumpling, crinkling’ sounds considered 'Crushing' sounds?
class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Crushing' sounds from ‘Tearing’ and ‘Crumpling, crinkling’. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Crushing' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples! You can also check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are eating like bitting or chewing sounds considered ‘Crushing’ sounds? class="content">

No, since it exists a better category for these kind of sounds. To help you decide, you can check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are walk, footstep sounds considered ‘Crushing’ sounds? class="content">

Not necessarily, only consider them ‘Crushing’ if it's audible that a foot is 'Crushing' something.

/m/09x0r.faq:
class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered 'Speech' sounds?
class="content">

Yes.

class="title"> Are heavily processed sounds (e.g., distorted or with audio effects) considered 'Speech' sounds? class="content">

Only consider them 'Speech' if the sounds are easy to recognize.

/m/01kcd.faq:
class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Brass instrument’ sounds?
class="content">

Only consider them ‘Brass instrument' if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not present.

class="title"> Are ‘Wind instrument, woodwind instrument' sounds considered 'Brass instrument' sounds? class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Brass instrument' sounds from ‘Wind instrument, woodwind instrument’. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Brass instrument' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

/m/03l9g.faq:
class="title"> Are ‘Jackhammer’ sounds considered 'Hammer' sounds?
class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Hammer' sounds from ‘Jackhammer’ ones. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Hammer' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples! You can also check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are pickaxe or pick sounds considered 'Hammer' sounds? class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Hammer' sounds from other tools. You can also check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

/m/01m4t.faq:
class="title"> Are beeppings or paper sounds considered 'Print' sounds?
class="content">

No, as long as they are not generated by 'Mechanisms'. When 'Print' and beeppings or paper sounds are all salient sounds, please choose Present but not predominant. You can also check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are 'Cash register' sounds considered 'Print' sounds? class="content">

Not necessarily, only consider them ‘Print’ if the printing sound is audible. When 'Print' and 'Cash register' are both salient sounds, please choose Present but not predominant.

/t/dd00077.faq:
class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Mechanisms’ sounds?
class="content">

Only consider them ‘Mechanisms’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not present.

class="title"> What type of sounds are included in ‘Mechanisms’? class="content">

Remember to check the description and direct children like 'Clock', 'Ratchet, pawl' or 'Gear' to understand what type of sounds are considered ‘Mechanisms’ sounds. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

class="title"> Are ‘Engine’ sounds considered 'Mechanisms' sounds? class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Mechanisms' sounds from ‘Engine’. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Mechanisms' from other similar categories. When ‘Mechanisms’ and ‘Engine’ are both salient sounds, please choose Present but not predominant. You can also check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

/m/05mxj0q.faq:
class="title"> Are 'Velcro, hook and loop fastener' sounds considered 'Packing tape, duct tape' sounds?
class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish them. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Packing tape, duct tape' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

class="title"> Are sounds of tearing materials considered 'Packing tape, duct tape' sounds? class="content">

No. Only sounds associated with self-adhesive tape must be considered, as specified in the Description.

/m/03m5k.faq:
class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Harp’ sounds?
class="content">

Only consider them ‘Harp’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not present.

class="title"> Are piano sounds considered 'Harp' sounds? class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Harp' sounds from pianos or keyboards. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Harp' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples! You can also check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are Jew's harp (also known as the jaw harp, mouth harp, Ozark harp or juice harp) sounds considered ‘Harp’ sounds? class="content">

No, since it is not a stringed musical instrument (see Description).

/m/03qjg.faq:
class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Harmonica’ sounds?
class="content">

Only consider them ‘Harmonica’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not present.

class="title"> Are heavily processed sounds (e.g., distorted or with audio effects) considered ‘Harmonica’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Harmonica’ if the sounds are easy to recognize.

/m/07r10fb.faq:
