class="title"> Are sounds of objects thrown or dropped to the water considered ‘Raindrop’ sounds?
class="content">

No. To help you decide, you can check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are all sounds of water drops considered ‘Raindrop’ sounds? class="content">

Not necessarily, only consider them ‘Raindrop’ if they sound very similar to or they are credible for a raindrop.

/m/0cmf2.faq:
class="title"> Are ‘Helicopter’ sounds considered 'Fixed-wing aircraft, airplane' sounds?
class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Fixed-wing aircraft, airplane' sounds from ‘Helicopter’. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Fixed-wing aircraft, airplane' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples! You can also check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are static cabin noise, pilot or cabin crew announcements considered ‘Fixed-wing aircraft, airplane’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Fixed-wing aircraft, airplane’ if the sound comes from the inside of an audible airplane.

class="title"> Are propeller planes considered ‘Fixed-wing aircraft, airplane’ sounds? class="content">

No. To help you decide, you can check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

/m/019jd.faq:
class="title"> Are seagull, horns or marina ambience sounds considered ‘Boat, Water vehicle’ sounds?
class="content">

Yes, as long as the sound is associated with the category ‘Boat, Water vehicle'. For example, mast, mooring, sail, rope or anchor sounds are accepted.

class="title"> Are ‘Motor vehicle (road)’ or ‘Rail transport’ sounds considered 'Boat, Water vehicle' sounds? class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Boat, Water vehicle' sounds from ‘Motor vehicle (road)’ or ‘Rail transport’. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Boat, Water vehicle' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples! You can also check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Boat, Water vehicle’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Boat, Water vehicle’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not present.

/m/01hsr_.faq:
class="title"> Are 'Cough' or 'Sniff' sounds considered 'Sneeze' sounds?
class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Cough' or 'Sniff' sounds from ‘Sneeze’ sounds. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Sneeze' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

class="title"> Are sneeze dog sounds considered ‘Sneeze’ sounds? class="content">

No, only consider them ‘Sneeze’ if they are generated by a human (see hierarchy).

/m/07pqc89.faq:
class="title"> Are drip and splash, splatter sounds considered ‘Trickle, dribble’ sounds?
class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish ‘Trickle, dribble’ sounds from drip and splash, splatter. You can also check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Is a single drop sound considered ‘Trickle, dribble’ sound? class="content">

No.

class="title"> Are stream, fountain, waterfall or faucet sounds considered ‘Trickle, dribble’ sounds? class="content">

Only if the liquid flowing slowly in an unsteady stream or drops is audible.

class="title"> Are fill (with liquid) sounds considered ‘Trickle, dribble’ sounds? class="content">

Only if the liquid flowing slowly in an unsteady stream or drops is audible. When ‘Trickle, dribble’ and fill (with liquid) are both salient sounds, please choose Present but not predominant.

/m/03kmc9.faq:
class="title"> Are 'Car alarm’, 'Alarm clock', 'Buzzer', 'Foghorn' or 'Fire alarm' sounds considered 'Siren' sounds?
class="content">

Not necessarily, be sure to distinguish 'Siren' sounds from 'Car alarm’, 'Alarm clock', 'Buzzer', 'Foghorn' or 'Fire alarm'. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Siren' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples! You can also check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Siren’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Siren’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas and unrealistic samples should be rated as Not present. You can also check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

/m/01jt3m.faq:
class="title"> Are ‘Sink (filling or washing)’, ‘ Water tap, faucet’ sounds, or other sounds related to a bathroom considered 'Toilet flush' sounds?
class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Toilet flush' sounds from other sounds that may be generated with water, but that they are not a toilet flushing. You can also check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are toilet flushing sounds that are recorded in toilets of ships/aircrafts considered 'Toilet flush' sounds? class="content">

Yes.

class="title"> Are cistern filling with water sounds after flushing considered 'Toilet flush' sounds? class="content">

Yes.

class="title"> Are ‘Toilet flush’ sounds containing peeing or washing hands sounds considered Present and predominant sounds? class="content">

No. When ‘Toilet flush’, peeing or washing hands are all salient sounds, please choose Present but not predominant.

/m/07s0dtb.faq:
class="title"> Are breathing, sniff or sneeze sounds considered 'Gasp' sounds?
class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish breathing, sniff or sneeze sounds from ‘Gasp’ sounds. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Gasp' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

class="title"> Are ‘Sigh’ sounds considered 'Gasp' sounds? class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Sigh' sounds from ‘Gasp’ ones. The difference between gasp and sigh is that gasp is a short, sudden intake of breath while sigh is a deep and prolonged audible inspiration or respiration of air, as when fatigued, frustrated, grieved, or relieved; the act of sighing.

class="title"> Are ‘Pant’ sounds considered 'Gasp' sounds? class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Gasp' sounds from ‘Pant’. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Gasp' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

/m/05zppz.faq:
class="title"> Are grunts, shouts or singing considered 'Male speech, man speaking' sounds?
class="content">

No, only consider them 'Male speech, man speaking' if you hear a man speaking.

class="title"> Are 'Speech synthesizer' or 'Child speech, kid speaking' sounds considered ‘Male speech, man speaking’ sounds? class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Male speech, man speaking' sounds from 'Speech synthesizer' or 'Child speech, kid speaking'. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Male speech, man speaking' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

class="title"> Are teenage male sounds considered 'Male speech, man speaking' sounds? class="content">

No, since they timbre can differ from what we consider 'Male speech, man speaking' sounds.

class="title"> Are man speaking through a walkie-talkie or telephone considered 'Male speech, man speaking' sounds? class="content">

Yes, as far as the speech is uttered by an adult male human.

class="title"> Are whispering sounds considered 'Male speech, man speaking' sounds? class="content">

No, since it exists a category for that concept: Human sounds > Human voice > Whispering.

/m/05tny_.faq:
class="title"> Are ‘Yip’ or ‘Bow-wow’ sounds considered 'Bark' sounds?
class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Bark' sounds from ‘Yip’ and 'Bow-wow’. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Bark' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

/m/020bb7.faq:
class="title"> Are human imitations considered ‘Bird vocalization, bird call, bird song’ sounds?
class="content">

Only consider them ‘Bird vocalization, bird call, bird song’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad imitations should be rated as Not present.

class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Bird vocalization, bird call, bird song’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Bird vocalization, bird call, bird song’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not present.

class="title"> Are ‘Gull, seagull’, ‘Crow’, 'Pigeon, dove' or ‘Owl’ sounds considered 'Bird vocalization, bird call, bird song' sounds? class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Bird vocalization, bird call, bird song' sounds from ‘Gull, seagull’, ‘Crow’, 'Pigeon, dove' or ‘Owl’. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Bird vocalization, bird call, bird song' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples! You can also check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

/m/0bm0k.faq:
class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Crash cymbal’ sounds?
class="content">

Bad replicas or drum machines should be rated as Not present.

class="title"> Are heavily processed sounds (e.g., distorted or with audio effects) considered ‘Crash cymbal’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Crash cymbal’ if the sounds are easy to recognize.

class="title"> Are other cymbal type sounds (e.g., 'Hi-hat') considered ‘Crash cymbal’ sounds? class="content">

No.

class="title"> Are atypical uses of the crash cymbal (e.g., playing the upper "bell" part of it) considered ‘Crash cymbal’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Crash cymbal’ if the source is easy to recognize.

/m/0l14md.faq:
class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Percussion’ sounds?
class="content">

Bad replicas should be rated as Not present.

/m/07r4wb8.faq:
class="title"> Are sounds of doors closing considered 'Knock' sounds?
class="content">

No. Understanding the siblings will help you distinguish 'Knock' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

class="title"> Are loud knock sounds still considered 'Knock' sounds? class="content">

Yes, as long as the sound can be considered as a natural knock. However, if the sound is notably loud, the 'Bang' category is more appropriate.

class="title"> Are you not sure what to decide with single impact sounds? class="content">

You can check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

/m/06rvn.faq:
class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Snare drum’ sounds?
class="content">

Only consider them ‘Snare drum’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not present.

class="title"> Are beatbox sounds considered ‘Snare drum’ sounds? class="content">

No, since it exists a category for beatbox sounds.

/m/026t6.faq:
class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Drum’ sounds?
class="content">

Bad replicas or drum machines should be rated as Not present.

class="title"> Are beatbox sounds considered ‘Drum’ sounds? class="content">

No, since it exists a category for beatbox sounds.

/m/07q2z82.faq:
class="title"> Are acceleration, revving or vroom sounds of non vehicle engines considered ‘Accelerating, revving, vroom’ sounds?
class="content">

Only consider them ‘Accelerating, revving, vroom’ if the sound is made by the engine of a vehicle (see Description).

class="title"> Are 'Engine starting', 'Engine knocking' or 'Idling' sounds considered 'Accelerating, revving, vroom' sounds? class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Accelerating, revving, vroom' sounds from'Engine starting', 'Engine knocking' and 'Idling'. When ‘Accelerating, revving, vroom’, ‘Engine starting’, 'Engine knocking' and 'Idling' are all salient sounds, please choose Present but not predominant. You can also check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are vehicle sounds (i.e., car or motorbikes passing by) considered ‘Accelerating, revving, vroom’ sounds? class="content">

Yes, as long as the accelerating, revving or vroom sound is audible.

/m/0l14_3.faq:
class="title"> Are plucking bowed string instrument sounds considered ‘Bowed string instrument’ sounds?
class="content">

Yes.

class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Bowed string instrument’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Bowed string instrument’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not present.

/m/04_sv.faq:
class="title"> Are 'Motorcycle' sounds containing 'Traffic noise, roadway noise' or 'Car' sounds considered Present and predominant sounds?
class="content">

No. When ‘Motorcycle’ and 'Traffic noise, roadway noise' or 'Car' are all salient sources, please choose Present but not predominant.

class="title"> Are alarm, horn, siren or brake sounds considered ‘Motorcycle’? class="content">

Yes, as long as the sound is clearly associated with the category 'Motorcycle’. When ‘Motorcycle’ and other sound sources (e.g., alarm, horn, siren or brake) are all salient, please choose Present but not predominant.

/m/01qbl.faq:
class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Cymbal’ sounds?
class="content">

Only consider them ‘Cymbal’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not present.

class="title"> Are beatbox sounds considered ‘Cymbal’ sounds? class="content">

No, since it exists a category for beatbox sounds.

/m/02bm9n.faq:
class="title"> Are ratchet musical instrument or ratchet tool sounds considered 'Ratchet, pawl' sounds?
class="content">

Yes, as long as the ' Ratchet, pawl' mechanism is audible. You can also check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

/m/0642b4.faq:
class="title"> Are 'Drawer (open or close)' sounds considered 'Cupboard (open or close)' sounds?
class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish them. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Cupboard (open or close)' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples! You can also check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are 'Door' sounds considered 'Cupboard (open or close)' sounds? class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish them. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Cupboard (open or close)' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples! You can also check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are filing cabinet sounds considered 'Cupboard (open or close)' sounds? class="content">

No. Filing cabinet sounds are more appropriate in the 'Drawer open or close' category. To help you decide, you can check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are bathroom cabinet sounds considered 'Cupboard (open or close)' sounds? class="content">

Yes. To help you decide, you can check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are creaking cupboard door sounds considered 'Cupboard (open or close)' sounds? class="content">

Yes. To help you decide, you can check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

/m/03qtq.faq:
class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Hi-hat’ sounds?
class="content">

Bad replicas or drum machines should be rated as Not present.

class="title"> Are heavily processed sounds (e.g., distorted or with audio effects) considered ‘Hi-hat’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Hi-hat’ if the sounds are easy to recognize.

class="title"> Are other cowbell or cymbal type sounds (e.g. 'Crash cymbal') considered ‘Hi-hat’ sounds? class="content">

No.

class="title"> Are beatbox sounds considered ‘Hi-hat’ sounds? class="content">

No.

class="title"> Are atypical uses of the hi-hat (e.g., playing the upper "bell" part of it) considered ‘Hi-hat’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Hi-hat’ if the source is easy to recognize.

/m/07qjznt.faq:
class="title"> Are tick-tock clock sounds considered ‘Tick’ sounds?
class="content">

Not necessarily, only consider them ‘Tick’ if they are presented as individual metallic tapping sounds. Steady recurrent ticking sounds made by a clock should be rated as Not Present since these are 'Tick-tock' sounds.
Click on any category for checking its description and examples to better understand other similar categories!

class="title"> Are human imitations considered ‘Tick’ sounds? class="content">

Yes, as far as they phonetically imitate, resemble, or suggest the ‘Tick’ sound (see the 'Onomatopoeia' description). Bad replicas should be rated as Not present.

class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Tick’ sounds? class="content">

Yes, as far as they phonetically imitate, resemble, or suggest the ‘Tick’ sound (see the 'Onomatopoeia' description). Bad replicas should be rated as Not present.

class="title"> Are heavily processed sounds (e.g., distorted or with audio effects) considered ‘Tick’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Tick’ if the sounds are easy to recognize.

/m/07q8k13.faq:
class="title"> Are squealing sounds considered 'Screech' sounds?
class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Screech' sounds from 'Squeal'. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Screech' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

class="title"> How are typical examples of 'Screech' sounds? class="content">

'Screech' sounds are often high-pitched and rough or metallic, sometimes related with rusty-like materials that produce sounds that set your teeth on edge.

/m/01x3z.faq:
class="title"> Are alarm clock or cuckoo clock sounds considered ‘Clock’ sounds?
class="content">

Not necessarily, only consider them ‘Clock’ if the clock is audible. Also note that the category 'Alarm Clock' is more appropriate for them.

class="title"> Are bell sounds considered ‘Clock’ sounds? class="content">

Not necessarily, only consider them ‘Clock’ if the clock is audible. Consider choosing Present but not predominant if necessary.

class="title"> Are winding up sounds considered ‘Clock’ sounds? class="content">

Yes, as long as the winded up mechanism is a 'Clock'. To help you decide, you can check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

/m/07cx4.faq:
class="title"> Are voices carried via the telephone network considered ‘Telephone’ sounds?
class="content">

No, see the Definition.

class="title"> Are pick up or hang up the phone sounds considered ‘Telephone’ sounds? class="content">

Yes, as long as those sounds are associated with the device itself. In this category, non-alarm sounds that comply with the Description are accepted (even though this is not fully consistent with the Hierarchy).

class="title"> Are sounds of typing messages on a cell phone considered ‘Telephone’ sounds? class="content">

No, the 'Typing' category is more appropriate for this kind of sounds.

/m/03qtwd.faq:
class="title"> What is the difference between 'Crowd' and 'Chatter'?
class="content">

'Crowd' refers to the sound of a large group of people gathered together (e.g., a political rally or a sports event) where the sound perceived seems to come from the crowd altogether, being very difficult to perceive each individual (simultaneous) human sound. On the contrary, 'Chatter' refers to the sound of casual speech by many people in individual simultaneous conversations. That is, the sound provides a sense of individual conversations happening simultaneously, and some words may be occasionally understood.

class="title"> Are heavily processed sounds (e.g., distorted or with audio effects) considered ‘Crowd’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Crowd’ if the sounds are easy to recognize.

/m/07qjznl.faq:
class="title"> Are individual 'Tick' sounds considered ‘Tick-tock’ sounds?
class="content">

No, since these are not steady recurrent ticking sounds (see the definition).

class="title"> Are not-clock sounds considered 'Tick-tock' sounds? class="content">

No, see the definition. To help you decide, you can check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are alarm clock, cukoo clock or ding-dong (door bell) sounds considered 'Tick-tock' sounds? class="content">

No. When 'Tick-tock' and alarm clock or cukoo clock are both salient sounds please choose Present but not predominant.

class="title"> Are human imitations considered ‘Tick-tock’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Tick-tock’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad imitations should be rated as Not Present.

/m/04k94.faq:
class="title"> Are swallowing, slurping or gurgling sounds considered ‘Liquid’ sounds?
class="content">

Not necessarily, only consider them ‘Liquid’ if the liquid sound is audible. When 'Liquid', swallowing, slurping or gurgling are all salient sounds, please choose Present but not predominant.

class="title"> Are rain, ocean and stream sounds considered ‘Liquid’ sounds? class="content">

Not necessarily, only consider them ‘Liquid’ if the liquid sound is audible.

class="title"> Are growling stomach sounds considered ‘Liquid’ sounds? class="content">

No, the 'Stomach rumble' category is more appropriate for this kind of sounds.

class="title"> Are ‘Liquid’ sounds containing fizzy or gassy sounds considered Present and predominant sounds? class="content">

No. When ‘Liquid’ and fizzy or gassy sounds are all salient sounds, please choose Present but not predominant.

/m/0fqfqc.faq:
class="title"> Are cash register sounds considered ‘Drawer open or close’ sounds?
class="content">

Not necessarily, only consider them ‘Drawer open or close’ if the sound of a drawer opening or closing is audible. If both the cash register and the drawer are recognizable, consider choosing Present but not predominant.

class="title"> Are 'Cupboard (open or close)' sounds considered 'Drawer (open or close)' sounds? class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish them. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Drawer (open or close)' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples! You can also check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are drawer rattle sounds (for example the sound of looking for something inside a drawer) considered 'Drawer (open or close)' sounds? class="content">

No. Only consider them 'Drawer (open or close)' if the sound of opening or closing a drawer is audible. If both sounds are salient, please choose Present but not predominant.

class="title"> Are sounds of opening or closing a drawer accompanied by the rattling sound of items loose inside the drawer considered Present and predominant? class="content">

No. If both sounds are salient, please choose Present but not predominant.

/m/07r04.faq:
class="title"> Are alarm, horn, siren, brake, seat belt and door sounds considered ‘Truck’ sounds?
class="content">

Yes, as long as the sound is associated with the category ‘Truck’.

class="title"> Are ‘Traffic noise, roadway noise’, ‘Car’ and ‘Emergency vehicle’ sounds considered ‘Truck’ sounds? class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Truck' sounds from ‘Traffic noise, roadway noise’, ‘Car’ and ‘Emergency vehicle’. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Truck' from other similar categories. When 'Truck' and the rest of the sounds are all salient, please choose Present but not predominant. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

class="title"> Are waste collection trucks considered ‘Truck’ sounds? class="content">

Yes, as long as the sound is associated with the category ‘Truck’.

class="title"> What type of sounds are included in ‘Truck’? class="content">

Remember to check the description and direct children to understand what type of sounds are considered ‘Truck’ sounds. For example, pick up trucks and dodge trucks are big cars, so they are not considered 'Truck'. You can also check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

/m/07r660_.faq:
class="title"> Are ‘Snicker’, ‘Belly laugh’, 'Chuckle, chortle' or ‘Baby laughter’ sounds considered 'Giggle' sounds?
class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Giggle' sounds from ‘Snicker’, ‘Belly laugh’, 'Chuckle, chortle' and ‘Baby laughter’. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Giggle' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples! If some of these similar categories are also salient in the audio sample, please choose Present but not predominant.

class="title"> Are ‘Baby laughter’ sounds considered 'Giggle' sounds? class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Giggle' sounds from ‘Baby laughter’. Laughter produced by a baby or infant must fall only under the ‘Baby laughter’ category. Therefore, please choose Not present.

class="title"> Are babies giggling considered 'Giggle' sounds? class="content">

Yes, since they are giggling.

/m/0dwtp.faq:
class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered 'Glockenspiel' sounds?
class="content">

Only consider them 'Glockenspiel' if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not present.

class="title"> Are heavily processed sounds (e.g., distorted or with audio effects) considered ‘Glockenspiel’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Glockenspiel’ if the sounds are easy to recognize.

class="title"> Are 'Marimba, xylophone', 'Vibraphone' or Metallophone sounds considered 'Glockenspiel' sounds? class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Glockenspiel' sounds from 'Marimba, xylophone', 'Vibraphone' and Metallophone. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Glockenspiel' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

class="title"> Are toy glockenspiel sounds considered ‘Glockenspiel’ sounds? class="content">

Yes, as long as they are related with the Description of ‘Glockenspiel’.

/m/06mb1.faq:
class="title"> Are ‘Stream’ or ‘Water fall’ sounds considered 'Rain' sounds?
class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Rain' sounds from ‘Stream’ and ‘Water fall’. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Rain' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples! You can also check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are rainstick percussion sounds considered ‘Rain’ sounds? class="content">

No.

class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Rain’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Rain’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not present.

/m/07jdr.faq:
class="title"> Are announcement sounds considered ‘Train’ sounds?
class="content">

Not necessarily, only consider them ‘Train’ if they come from the interior of the train. To help you decide, you can check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are ‘Subway, metro, underground’ sounds considered 'Train’ sounds? class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish ‘Subway, metro, underground’ sounds from 'Train'. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Train' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

class="title"> Are rack railway or cable car sounds considered ‘Train’ sounds? class="content">

Yes, as long as the sound is associated with the category ‘Train’. To help you decide, it's best to check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are 'Train wheels squealing' sounds considered ‘Train’ sounds? class="content">

Yes. Although it is a sibling, we accept it in this case.

/m/05r5c.faq:
class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Piano’ sounds?
class="content">

Only consider them ‘Piano’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not present.

class="title"> Are atypical uses of the piano considered Piano’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Piano’ if the source is easy to recognize.

/m/0fx9l.faq:
class="title"> Are the sounds of a microwave opening/closing considered ‘Microwave oven' sounds?
class="content">

Yes, as long as the sound is produced by a microwave oven.

class="title"> Are "beep" sounds considered ‘Microwave oven’ sounds? class="content">

Yes, as long as the sound is produced by a microwave oven. To help you decide, you can check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are oven or stove sounds considered ‘Microwave oven’ sounds? class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish oven or stove sounds from 'Microwave oven' sounds. To help you decide, you can check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

/m/0lyf6.faq:
class="title"> Are yawn sounds considered ‘Breathing’ sounds?
class="content">

Not necessarily, only consider them ‘Breathing’ if the breathing sound is audible.

class="title"> Are 'Sniff', 'Cough' or 'Sneeze' sounds considered ‘Breathing’ sounds? class="content">

Not necessarily, be sure to distinguish 'Breathing' sounds from'Sniff', 'Cough' and 'Sneeze'. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Breathing' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

class="title"> Are non-human sounds considered ‘Breathing’ sounds? class="content">

No, see the Hierarchy.

class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Breathing’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Breathing’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not present.

class="title"> Are heavily processed sounds (e.g., distorted or with audio effects) considered ‘Breathing’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Breathing’ if the sounds are easy to recognize.

/m/032s66.faq:
class="title"> Are ‘Fireworks’ or ‘Boom’ sounds considered 'Gunshot, gunfire' sounds?
class="content">

Not necessarily, be sure to distinguish 'Gunshot, gunfire' sounds from ‘Fireworks’ or ‘Boom’. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Gunshot, gunfire' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples! You can also check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are human imitations considered ‘Gunshot, gunfire’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Gunshot, gunfire’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad imitations should be rated as Not present.

class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Gunshot, gunfire’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Gunshot, gunfire’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not present.

class="title"> Are laser-gun sounds considered ‘Gunshot, gunfire’ sounds? class="content">

No, since they are not the sound of the discharge of a firearm (see Description).

class="title"> Are sounds of loading a gun or bullet shells falling down considered ‘Gunshot, gunfire’ sounds? class="content">

If the sound contains only the sound of loading a gun or bullet shells falling down (but not the sound of the discharge of a firearm), please choose Not Present. However, if both are salient sources (i.e., the discharge of a firearm and something else), please choose Present but not predominant.

/m/05148p4.faq:
class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Keyboard (musical)’ sounds?
class="content">

Only consider them ‘Keyboard (musical)’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not present.

class="title"> Are heavily processed sounds (e.g., distorted or with audio effects) considered ‘Keyboard (musical)’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Keyboard (musical)’ if the sounds are easy to recognize.

class="title"> Synthesized sounds considered ‘Keyboard (musical)’ sounds? class="content">

Not necessarily, only consider them ‘Keyboard (musical)’ if a keyboard is involved in the generation of the synthesized sound.

/m/01bjv.faq:
class="title"> Are ‘Bus’ sounds containing chattering sounds or next stop announcements considered Present and predominant?
class="content">

Yes. Recordings made inside a bus that contain the typical sounds found in the interior of a bus are considered Present and predominant.

class="title"> Are public address systems in bus stations considered ‘Bus’ sounds? class="content">

No, as long as they are not generated inside a 'Bus'. When 'Bus' and station sounds are both salient sounds, please choose Present but not predominant.

class="title"> What can I do if I am not sure if a sound corresponds to 'Bus'? class="content">

You can check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

/m/0395lw.faq:
class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Bell’ sounds?
class="content">

Only consider them ‘Bell’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not present.

class="title"> Are phone ringtones or telephone ringing sounds considered ‘Bell’ sounds? class="content">

No, because it exists a better category for these kind of sounds: ''Sounds of things > Alarm > Telephone > Telephone bell ringing '.

class="title"> Are bell sounds from microwave ovens or typewriters considered ‘Bell’ sounds? class="content">

Yes.

class="title"> Are door bell sounds considered ‘Bell’ sounds? class="content">

No, because it exists a better category for these kind of sounds: 'Door > Doorbell'.

/m/04szw.faq:
class="title"> Are atypical uses of the musical instrument considered ‘Musical instrument’ sounds?
class="content">

Only consider them ‘Musical instrument’ if you can easily recognize it as an instrument.

class="title"> Are synthetic instrument sounds considered ‘Musical instrument’ sounds? class="content">

Yes.

/m/026fgl.faq:
class="title"> Are sounds of the instrument 'Chime' considered ‘Wind chime’ sounds?
class="content">

No. Only must be considered 'Wind chime' those sounds associated with this specific instrument, which are usually produced by the natural movement of air. The sounds from the instrument 'Chime' must fall under the 'Chime' category.

/m/06h7j.faq:
class="title"> Are ‘Walk, footsteps’ or ‘Shuffle’ sounds considered 'Run' sounds?
class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Run' sounds from ‘Walk, footsteps’ or ‘Shuffle’. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Run' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

class="title"> Are synthetic sounds considered ‘Walk, footsteps’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Walk, footsteps’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad replicas should be rated as Not present.

/m/0f8s22.faq:
class="title"> Are tubular bell sounds considered ‘Chime’ sounds?
class="content">

No.

class="title"> Are chimebar sounds considered ‘Chime’ sounds? class="content">

No. A chimebar is a percussion instrument consisting of a tuned metal bar similar to a glockenspiel. To help you decide, you can check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are wind chime sounds considered ‘Chime’ sounds? class="content">

Yes. 'Wind chime' is one example of 'Chime' (see Direct children).

/m/0199g.faq:
class="title"> Are ‘Bicycle bell’ sounds considered ‘Bicycle’ sounds?
class="content">

Yes, as long as the sound is associated with the category ‘Bicycle’ (note that ‘Bicycle bell’ is a direct children of 'Bicycle').

class="title"> Are horn sounds considered ‘Bicycle’ sounds? class="content">

No. When horn sounds and sounds of 'Bicycle' are both salient, please choose Present but not predominant. Remember that bicycle horns are not the same as 'Bicycle bell' sounds.

class="title"> Are air pumps considered ‘Bicycle’ sounds? class="content">

No.

/m/01h8n0.faq:
class="title"> Are the spoken communications done by a single individual considered ‘Conversation’?
class="content">

No, since it is not a 'spoken communication between two or more people' as per the description.

class="title"> Are the combined sound of several simultaneous conversations considered ‘Conversation’? class="content">

Only consider them 'Conversation' if you can distinguish at least one salient and/or intelligible conversation. In this case, please choose Present but not predominant. However, if none of them is salient, this sound is probably more appropriate in the 'Chatter' category, therefore please choose Not present.

/m/0130jx.faq:
class="title"> Are 'Bathtub (filling or washing)' sounds considered 'Sink (filling or washing)' sounds?
class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish them. Understanding the siblings will help you distinguish 'Sink (filling or washing)' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

class="title"> Are 'Water tap, faucet' sounds considered 'Sink (filling or washing)' sounds? class="content">

Yes, as long as the 'Sink (filling or washing)' is audible. When 'Sink (filling or washing)' and 'Water tap, faucet' are both salient sound, please choose Present but not predominant. You can also check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link to help you decide.

class="title"> Are sounds of liquid dripping considered 'Sink (filling or washing)' sounds? class="content">

Not necessarily, only consider them 'Sink (filling or washing)' if the sink is audible.

/m/02zsn.faq:
class="title"> Are 'Speech synthesizer' or 'Child speech, kid speaking' sounds considered ‘Female speech, woman speaking’ sounds?
class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish ‘Female speech, woman speaking’ sounds from ‘'Speech synthesizer' or 'Child speech, kid speaking'. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish ‘Female speech, woman speaking’ from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

class="title"> Are grunts, shouts or singing considered 'Female speech, woman speaking' sounds? class="content">

No, since these are not speech sounds (see hierarchy).

class="title"> Are whispering sounds considered 'Female speech, woman speaking' sounds? class="content">

No, since it exists a category for that concept: Human sounds > Human voice > Whispering.

/m/09ld4.faq:
class="title"> Are human imitations considered ‘Frog’ sounds?
class="content">

Only consider them ‘Frog’ if they sound as real as an original one. Bad imitations should be rated as Not present.

/m/02dgv.faq:
class="title"> Are ‘Cupboard open or close’ or 'Drawer open or close’ sounds considered 'Door' sounds?
class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Door' sounds from ‘Cupboard open or close’ or 'Drawer open or close’. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Door' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples! You can also check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are locking door sounds considered ‘Door’ sounds? class="content">

Yes, as long as the sound is related to a 'Door'.

class="title"> Are fridge and freezer door sounds considered ‘Door’ sounds? class="content">

Yes.

/m/07rkbfh.faq:
class="title"> Are all conversation sounds considered 'Chatter'?
class="content">

No. 'Chatter' is appropriate for the combined sound of casual speech by many people in individual simultaneous conversations. The typical 'Chatter' occurs when none of the conversations is particularly salient and/or intelligible. However, if you can distinguish at least one salient and/or intelligible conversation (with others in the background), please choose Present but not predominant as this sound sample could also be tagged as 'Conversation'.

class="title"> What is the difference between 'Chatter' and 'Crowd'? class="content">

We denote 'Chatter' as the sound of casual speech by many people in individual simultaneous conversations. That is, the sound provides a sense of individual conversations happening simultaneously, and some words may be occasionally understood. On the contrary, 'Crowd' refers to the sound of a larger group of people gathered together (e.g., a political rally or a sports event) where the sound perceived seems to come from the crowd altogether, being very difficult to perceive individual simultaneous conversations.

/m/02y_763.faq:
class="title"> Are sounds of elevators considered 'Sliding door' sounds?
class="content">

Not necessarily, only consider them ‘Sliding door’ if the sound of a door sliding is audible. If you can perceive other additional sounds, please choose Present but not predominant. Check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are regular door sounds considered 'Sliding door' sounds? class="content">

No, only sounds of doors that open horizontally by sliding are considered 'Sliding door'.

class="title"> Are ‘Sliding door’ sounds containing ‘Slam’ or 'Squeak' sounds considered Present and predominant sounds? class="content">

No. When ‘Sliding door’ and ‘Slam’ or 'Squeak' are all salient sounds, please choose Present but not predominant.

class="title"> Are non-domestic sounds (e.g., sliding door sounds from a prison or horse stall) considered ‘Sliding door’? class="content">

Yes, as long as they contain the sound of a type of door which opens horizontally by sliding, usually parallel to a wall. In this category, non-domestic sounds that comply with the Description are accepted (even though this is not fully consistent with the Hierarchy).

/m/07p7b8y.faq:
class="title"> Are 'Pour' or trickle, dribble sounds considered ‘Fill (with liquid)’ sounds?
class="content">

Not necessarily, only consider them ‘Fill (with liquid)’ if the liquid poured fills a container and that sound is audible. When ‘Fill (with liquid)’ and ‘Pour’ or trickle, dribble are all salient sounds, please choose Present but not predominant. To help you decide, you can check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are gurgle, hiss or fizz sounds considered ‘Fill (with liquid)’ sounds? class="content">

No. You can usually hear gurgles when a liquid is flowing through a narrow constriction, hissing sounds from a faucet and fizzy sounds from soda drinks. When ‘Fill (with liquid)’ and gurgle, hiss or fizz are all salient sounds, please choose Present but not predominant.

/m/03qc9zr.faq:
class="title"> Are ‘Shout’ sounds considered 'Screaming' sounds?
class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Screaming' sounds from ‘Shout’. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Screaming' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

class="title"> Are heavily processed sounds (e.g., distorted or with audio effects) considered ‘Screaming’ sounds? class="content">

Only consider them ‘Screaming’ if the sounds are easy to recognize.

class="title"> Are monster screams considered ‘Screaming’ sounds? class="content">

No, only consider them ‘Screaming’ if you can recognize a human.

/m/07pggtn.faq:
class="title"> Are ‘ Squawk’ sounds considered 'Chirp, tweet' sounds?
class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Chirp, tweet' sounds from ‘ Squawk’. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Chirp, tweet' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples!

class="title"> Are human imitations considered ‘Chirp, tweet’ sounds? class="content">

Yes, as far as they ‘Chirp, tweet’ if they phonetically imitate, resemble, or suggest the sound of a ‘Chirp, tweet’ (note that one of its parents is Onomatopoeia).

class="title"> Are (electronic) chirp signals considered ‘Chirp, tweet’ sounds? class="content">

No, since it exists a category for this type of sounds: Source-ambiguous sounds > Other sourceless > Sine wave > Chirp tone .

/m/02jz0l.faq:
class="title"> Are ‘Sink (filling or washing)’ or 'Bathtub (filling or washing)' sounds considered 'Water tap, faucet' sounds?
class="content">

Not necessarily, only consider them ‘Water tap, faucet’ if the faucet sound is audible. You can check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link to help you decide. Also, please consider choosing Present but not predominant if both are salient sounds.

class="title"> Are single drops, leaking or dripping sounds considered 'Water tap, faucet' sounds? class="content">

Yes, as long as the sounds are generated by a 'Water tap, faucet'. To help you decide, you can check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are draining sounds considered 'Water tap, faucet' sounds? class="content">

No, as long as these sounds are generated at the ‘Sink (filling or washing)’ or at the 'Bathtub (filling or washing)'. When 'Water tap, faucet' and draining are both salient sounds please choose Present but not predominant.

/m/0btp2.faq:
class="title"> Are only one or two cars passing by considered 'Traffic noise, roadway noise' sounds?
class="content">

No, there is a better category for those sounds.

class="title"> Are car horns or sirens sounds considered 'Traffic noise, roadway noise' sounds? class="content">

No, when 'Traffic noise, roadway noise' and car horns or sirens are all salient sounds, please choose Present but not predominant.

/m/03dnzn.faq:
class="title"> Are 'Sink (filling or washing)' sounds considered 'Bathtub (filling or washing)' sounds?
class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish them. Understanding the siblings will help you distinguish 'Bathtub (filling or washing)' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples! You can also check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link to help you decide.

class="title"> Are ' Water tap, faucet' sounds considered ‘Bathtub (filling or washing)’ sounds? class="content">

Not necessarily, only consider them ‘Bathtub (filling or washing)’ if the audible faucet sound is located in a bathtub. You can check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link to help you decide.

class="title"> Are shower sounds considered 'Bathtub (filling or washing)' sounds? class="content">

Yes, although the Description does not say it explicitly, we include shower sounds here.

class="title"> Are sounds of liquid dripping considered 'Bathtub (filling or washing)' sounds? class="content">

Not necesarilty, only if the sound is generated in a 'Bathtub (filling or washing)'. To help you decide, you can check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are sounds of bathtub curtains or doors considered 'Bathtub (filling or washing)' sounds? class="content">

No, as long as they are not related to filling or washing sounds.

/m/03wwcy.faq:
class="title"> Are 'Ding-dong' sounds considered ‘Doorbell’ sounds?
class="content">

Yes. 'Ding-dong' sounds are one example of 'Doorbell' and therefore they are valid sounds in 'Doorbell'.

class="title"> Are sounds of chimes, bells, generic 'Ding' sounds or any alert sound considered ‘Doorbell’ sounds? class="content">

Not necessarily. Only consider them 'Doorbell' if they come from a signaling device typically placed near a building's entrance with which a visitor can announce their presence to occupants. To help you decide, you can check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

class="title"> Are sounds of bicycle bells or microwave ovens considered ‘Doorbell’ sounds? class="content">

No. To help you decide, you can check the sounds’ metadata in Freesound by clicking the link.

/m/07k1x.faq:
class="title"> What type of sounds are included in ‘Tools’?
class="content">

Remember to check the description and direct children to understand what type of sounds are considered ‘Tools’ sounds.

class="title"> Are ‘Mechanisms’, like ratchets or gears, considered 'Tools' sounds? class="content">

No, be sure to distinguish 'Tools' sounds from ‘Mechanisms'. Understanding the siblings and direct children will help you distinguish 'Tools' from other similar categories. Click on any category to check its description and examples!
